_link.title: I can classify elements as metals, non-metals, or metalloids based on their position

toLevel2.question: Where are metals found on the periodic table?

options.text: On the left side and centre of the periodic table
On the far right side of the periodic table
options.explanation: The far right contains non-metals and noble gases, not metals.

options.text: Only in the top row of the periodic table
options.explanation: Metals are found across many rows on the left and centre, not just the top row.

options.text: Scattered randomly throughout the table
options.explanation: The periodic table is organised so metals are grouped on the left and centre.

toLevel2.question: Where are non-metals found on the periodic table?

options.text: On the right side of the periodic table
On the left side of the periodic table
options.explanation: The left side is where metals are located, not non-metals.

options.text: In the centre of the periodic table
options.explanation: The centre contains transition metals; non-metals are on the right.

options.text: Only at the bottom of the periodic table
options.explanation: Non-metals are in the upper right area, not at the bottom.

options.text: Elements that have properties of both metals and non-metals
Elements that are a mixture of two different metals
options.explanation: Metalloids are not mixtures; they are pure elements with intermediate properties.

options.text: Elements that are always liquids at room temperature
options.explanation: Metalloids are typically solids at room temperature, not liquids.

options.text: Elements that have no useful properties
options.explanation: Metalloids have important uses, such as silicon in semiconductors.

toLevel2.question: Where are metalloids found on the periodic table?

options.text: Along the staircase line between metals and non-metals
In the first column on the left
options.explanation: The first column contains alkali metals, not metalloids.

options.text: In the last column on the right
options.explanation: The last column contains noble gases, not metalloids.

options.text: In the centre of the periodic table
options.explanation: The centre contains transition metals; metalloids are along the metal/non-metal boundary.

toLevel2.question: Which of the following is an example of a metalloid?

options.text: Silicon
Sodium
options.explanation: Sodium is a metal found in Group 1, not a metalloid.

options.text: Oxygen
options.explanation: Oxygen is a non-metal found in Group 16.

options.text: Iron
options.explanation: Iron is a transition metal, not a metalloid.

toLevel2.template: Metals are found on the {{blank:1}} side of the periodic table, while non-metals are on the {{blank:2}} side.
Metalloids are found along the {{blank:1}} line that separates metals from {{blank:2}}.
Elements with properties of both metals and non-metals are called {{blank:1}}. An example is {{blank:2}}.

toLevel2.statement: Most elements in the periodic table are metals.
toLevel2.explanation: About 80% of the elements are metals, occupying the left and centre of the periodic table.

toLevel2.statement: Non-metals are found on the left side of the periodic table.
toLevel2.explanation: Non-metals are found on the right side of the periodic table; the left side contains metals.

toLevel3.question: Boron is found next to the staircase line on the periodic table. How should it be classified?

options.text: As a metalloid, because it is on the boundary between metals and non-metals
As a metal, because it is on the left side of the table
options.explanation: Although boron is in Group 13, it sits on the staircase line and has intermediate properties, making it a metalloid.

options.text: As a non-metal, because it is a poor conductor
options.explanation: While boron is a poor conductor compared to metals, it has some metallic properties and is classified as a metalloid.

options.text: As a noble gas, because it is unreactive
options.explanation: Boron is a solid element on the staircase line, not a noble gas in Group 18.

toLevel3.question: Carbon is in Group 14, to the right of the staircase line. How is carbon classified?

options.text: As a non-metal
As a metalloid because it is close to the staircase line
options.explanation: Although close to the line, carbon is on the non-metal side and has typical non-metal properties.

options.text: As a metal because diamond is very hard
options.explanation: Hardness alone does not make an element a metal; carbon lacks metallic properties like electrical conductivity.

options.text: As a metalloid because graphite conducts electricity
options.explanation: Graphite's conductivity is an exception; carbon is classified as a non-metal based on its position and overall properties.

toLevel3.question: Why is aluminium classified as a metal rather than a metalloid, even though it is close to the staircase line?

options.text: Because aluminium has typical metallic properties such as good conductivity, malleability, and a shiny appearance
Because aluminium is in a high-numbered group
options.explanation: Group number does not determine the classification; properties and position relative to the staircase line do.

options.text: Because aluminium is found in many everyday objects
options.explanation: How commonly an element is used does not determine its classification as metal, non-metal, or metalloid.

options.text: Because aluminium is a solid at room temperature
options.explanation: Many non-metals and metalloids are also solids; being solid does not make an element a metal.

toLevel3.question: A student says 'hydrogen must be a metal because it is on the left side of the periodic table.' Is this correct?

options.text: No; hydrogen is a non-metal despite its position, because it has non-metallic properties
Yes; anything on the left side is a metal
options.explanation: Hydrogen is an exception; it is placed in Group 1 due to its electron configuration but is a non-metal.

options.text: No; hydrogen is a metalloid
options.explanation: Hydrogen is a non-metal, not a metalloid; it is a gas with non-metallic properties.

options.text: Yes; hydrogen is an alkali metal in Group 1
options.explanation: Hydrogen is in Group 1 but is not an alkali metal; it is a non-metal with unique properties.

toLevel3.question: Which of the following correctly lists one metal, one non-metal, and one metalloid?

options.text: Iron (metal), sulfur (non-metal), germanium (metalloid)
Silicon (metal), chlorine (non-metal), boron (metalloid)
options.explanation: Silicon is a metalloid, not a metal; the list has two metalloids.

options.text: Copper (metal), neon (non-metal), carbon (metalloid)
options.explanation: Carbon is a non-metal, not a metalloid.

options.text: Sodium (metal), argon (metalloid), oxygen (non-metal)
options.explanation: Argon is a noble gas (non-metal), not a metalloid.

toLevel3.question: Germanium is in Group 14, Period 4, on the staircase line. What type of element is it?

options.text: A metalloid
A metal, because it is in Period 4 with many metals
options.explanation: Period number does not determine classification; germanium's position on the staircase line makes it a metalloid.

options.text: A non-metal, because it is in the same group as carbon
options.explanation: Being in the same group as carbon does not make it a non-metal; germanium is further down and on the staircase line.

options.text: A transition metal
options.explanation: Transition metals are in the central block (Groups 3–12); germanium is in Group 14 on the staircase line.

toLevel3.template: Hydrogen is placed in {{blank:1}} 1 but is classified as a {{blank:2}}, not a metal.
Silicon and germanium are both examples of {{blank:1}} found along the {{blank:2}} line on the periodic table.
To classify an element, first find its position on the periodic table: left side = {{blank:1}}, right side = non-metal, on the staircase = {{blank:2}}.

toLevel3.statement: All elements in Group 14 are classified as metalloids because silicon is a metalloid.
toLevel3.explanation: Group 14 contains carbon (non-metal), silicon and germanium (metalloids), and tin and lead (metals); classification varies within a group.

toLevel4.question: Arsenic (Group 15, Period 4) is on the staircase line and can act as a semiconductor. Based on this information, how should arsenic be classified?

options.text: As a metalloid, because it is on the staircase line and has intermediate properties
As a non-metal, because it is in the same group as nitrogen
options.explanation: Being in the same group as a non-metal does not automatically make an element a non-metal; position on the staircase line matters.

options.text: As a metal, because it has a shiny appearance
options.explanation: Some metalloids have a shiny appearance; overall position and properties determine classification.

options.text: As a transition metal, because it is in Period 4
options.explanation: Transition metals occupy Groups 3–12; arsenic is in Group 15 on the staircase line.

toLevel4.question: Tin (Sn) is in Group 14, Period 5, below germanium. Should tin be classified the same as germanium?

options.text: No; tin is below the staircase line and is classified as a metal, while germanium is on the line and is a metalloid
Yes; both are metalloids because they are in the same group
options.explanation: Group membership does not determine classification alone; position relative to the staircase line matters.

options.text: No; tin is a non-metal because it is further from the metals
options.explanation: Tin is below the staircase line on the metal side; it is a metal, not a non-metal.

options.text: Yes; both are metals because they are in Group 14
options.explanation: Germanium is on the staircase line and is a metalloid, not a metal.

toLevel4.question: A student is given an unknown element that is shiny, brittle, and a poor conductor of heat. How should they classify it?

options.text: As a metalloid, because it has some metal properties (shiny) and some non-metal properties (brittle, poor conductor)
As a metal, because it is shiny
options.explanation: Shininess alone is not enough; the brittleness and poor conductivity suggest intermediate properties.

options.text: As a non-metal, because it is brittle
options.explanation: The shiny appearance suggests some metallic character; the combination of properties indicates a metalloid.

options.text: It cannot be classified without knowing its name
options.explanation: Properties can be used to classify elements even before identification; this combination suggests a metalloid.

toLevel4.question: Antimony (Sb) is in Group 15, Period 5, on the staircase line. Bismuth (Bi) is in Group 15, Period 6, below the staircase line. How are they classified differently?

options.text: Antimony is a metalloid and bismuth is a metal
Both are metalloids because they are in the same group
options.explanation: Position relative to the staircase line differs; bismuth is below it and is a metal.

options.text: Both are metals because they are heavy elements
options.explanation: Mass does not determine classification; antimony's position on the staircase line makes it a metalloid.

options.text: Antimony is a metal and bismuth is a metalloid
options.explanation: This is reversed; antimony is on the staircase line (metalloid) and bismuth is below it (metal).

toLevel4.question: Going down Group 14: carbon, silicon, germanium, tin, lead. Which statement correctly describes the classification pattern?

options.text: Non-metal (C), metalloids (Si, Ge), metals (Sn, Pb)
All are metalloids because they are in the same group
options.explanation: Classification changes going down the group as elements cross from non-metal to metalloid to metal.

options.text: Non-metals (C, Si), metalloids (Ge), metals (Sn, Pb)
options.explanation: Silicon is a metalloid, not a non-metal; it sits on the staircase line.

options.text: Metals (Sn, Pb), non-metals (C, Si, Ge)
options.explanation: Silicon and germanium are metalloids, not non-metals.

toLevel4.question: Tellurium (Te, Group 16) is on the staircase line and is sometimes used in semiconductor devices. Selenium (Se, Group 16) is above it and to the right of the staircase line. How should each be classified?

options.text: Tellurium is a metalloid and selenium is a non-metal
Both are metalloids because they are in the same group
options.explanation: Selenium is above the staircase line on the non-metal side, so it is a non-metal.

options.text: Both are non-metals because they are in Group 16 with oxygen
options.explanation: Tellurium is on the staircase line and has intermediate properties, making it a metalloid.

options.text: Tellurium is a metal and selenium is a metalloid
options.explanation: Tellurium is on the staircase line (metalloid) and selenium is a non-metal.

toLevel4.question: Polonium (Po) is in Group 16, Period 6, below tellurium and below the staircase line. A student classifies it as a metalloid. Is this correct?

options.text: No; polonium is below the staircase line and is classified as a metal
Yes; all elements in Group 16 near the bottom are metalloids
options.explanation: Classification depends on position relative to the staircase; polonium is below it, so it is a metal.

options.text: Yes; polonium has intermediate properties
options.explanation: Polonium is generally classified as a metal based on its position below the staircase line.

options.text: No; polonium is a non-metal like oxygen in the same group
options.explanation: Polonium is below the staircase line; elements further down Group 16 become more metallic.

toLevel4.template: Going down Group 14, elements change from {{blank:1}} (carbon) to metalloids to {{blank:2}} (tin, lead).
Elements become more {{blank:1}} in character as you go down a group, which is why tin is a metal while {{blank:2}} above it is a metalloid.
The staircase line runs from {{blank:1}} (Group 13) diagonally down to astatine (Group 17), separating metals from {{blank:2}}.

toLevel5.question: Silicon is a metalloid that can act as a semiconductor. A student argues that because silicon conducts electricity under certain conditions, it should be reclassified as a metal. Evaluate this argument.

options.text: The argument is flawed; semiconductivity is a property of metalloids, not metals, which are full conductors
The argument is correct; any element that conducts electricity is a metal
options.explanation: Metals are full conductors; semiconductors have intermediate conductivity, which is characteristic of metalloids.

options.text: The argument is correct because silicon is shiny like a metal
options.explanation: Shininess alone does not make an element a metal; silicon has intermediate properties overall.

options.text: The argument is flawed because silicon does not actually conduct electricity
options.explanation: Silicon does conduct under certain conditions; that is what makes it a semiconductor and metalloid.

toLevel5.question: Astatine is in Group 17 (halogens) but is sometimes classified as a metalloid. Why might its classification be debated?

options.text: Because astatine is at the bottom of Group 17 near the staircase line, and elements become more metallic going down a group
Because astatine is radioactive, so it cannot be classified
options.explanation: Radioactivity does not affect metal/non-metal classification; position and properties do.

options.text: Because all halogens are metalloids
options.explanation: Most halogens (F, Cl, Br, I) are clearly non-metals; only astatine at the bottom is debated.

options.text: Because astatine is a gas like the other halogens
options.explanation: Astatine is predicted to be a solid; its properties differ from lighter halogens.

toLevel5.question: A student claims: 'The staircase line is a perfect boundary — everything to the left is a metal and everything to the right is a non-metal.' Evaluate this statement.

options.text: It is an oversimplification; elements on the staircase line are metalloids, and hydrogen is a non-metal despite being on the left
The statement is completely correct with no exceptions
options.explanation: Hydrogen is on the left but is a non-metal, and elements on the line itself are metalloids.

options.text: The statement is wrong because the staircase line does not exist
options.explanation: The staircase line is a real feature used to separate metals from non-metals on the periodic table.

options.text: The statement is correct except that noble gases are neither metals nor non-metals
options.explanation: Noble gases are classified as non-metals; the real exceptions are hydrogen and the metalloids.

toLevel5.question: Compare the trend in metallic character going across Period 3 (Na to Ar) with the trend going down Group 14 (C to Pb). How do these trends relate to classification?

options.text: Metallic character decreases across a period (metal → metalloid → non-metal) and increases down a group (non-metal → metalloid → metal)
Metallic character increases in both directions
options.explanation: Across a period, metallic character decreases; only down a group does it increase.

options.text: Metallic character is constant across a period and only changes down a group
options.explanation: Metallic character clearly changes across Period 3, from sodium (metal) to argon (non-metal).

options.text: Metallic character decreases in both directions
options.explanation: Down a group, metallic character increases, not decreases.

toLevel5.question: Graphite (a form of carbon) conducts electricity, and diamond (another form of carbon) does not. A student says this means carbon should be classified as both a metal and a non-metal. What is the best response?

options.text: Carbon is classified as a non-metal based on its position and overall properties; individual allotropes having different properties does not change the element's classification
The student is correct; carbon is a metalloid because of its dual behaviour
options.explanation: Carbon is clearly on the non-metal side of the staircase line; one conductive allotrope does not change its classification.

options.text: The student is correct; carbon should be reclassified as a metal
options.explanation: One allotrope conducting electricity does not override carbon's overall non-metallic classification.

options.text: The student is wrong because graphite does not actually conduct electricity
options.explanation: Graphite does conduct electricity due to delocalised electrons; but this does not change carbon's classification.

toLevel5.question: If a new element were synthesised and placed in Group 15, Period 8, where would you predict its position relative to the staircase line, and how would you classify it?

options.text: Below the staircase line; it would likely be a metal due to the trend of increasing metallic character down a group
On the staircase line; it would be a metalloid like arsenic
options.explanation: Going further down the group moves elements below the staircase line; antimony is the metalloid in Group 15.

options.text: Above the staircase line; it would be a non-metal like nitrogen
options.explanation: Elements further down a group are more metallic, not less; it would not be a non-metal.

options.text: It cannot be predicted because new elements behave unpredictably
options.explanation: Periodic trends allow reasonable predictions; increasing metallic character down a group suggests it would be a metal.

toLevel5.question: A researcher discovers that a metalloid can be converted into either a better conductor or a better insulator by adding small amounts of other elements (doping). Why does this property make metalloids particularly useful in technology?

options.text: Because their intermediate conductivity can be tuned, allowing them to function as semiconductors in electronic devices
Because it proves metalloids are actually metals
options.explanation: Being tunable does not reclassify them; it highlights their intermediate nature as metalloids.

options.text: Because doping changes the metalloid into a non-metal
options.explanation: Doping modifies conductivity but does not change the element's fundamental classification.

options.text: Because only metalloids can have impurities added to them
options.explanation: Any material can be doped; metalloids are special because doping changes their conductivity in useful ways.

toLevel5.question: Iodine (Group 17) is a non-metal but has a shiny, metallic appearance. How does this challenge simple classification rules?

options.text: It shows that appearance alone cannot determine classification; position on the periodic table and overall properties must be considered together
It means iodine should be reclassified as a metalloid
options.explanation: Iodine is clearly a non-metal based on its position and most properties; lustre alone does not change classification.

options.text: It proves that the periodic table classification system is wrong
options.explanation: One exception does not invalidate the system; it shows that multiple properties must be considered.

options.text: It has no relevance to classification because only metals can be shiny
options.explanation: Some non-metals like iodine are shiny, showing that lustre alone is not a reliable classifier.
